p: Ranpirnase is currently being repurposed as an antiviral drug and is under investigation for broad spectrum activity against double-stranded DNA viruses [ 15], retroviruses [ 16, 17], and single-stranded RNA viruses including Ebola virus [ 18]. Phase I and II clinical trials have been completed for the topical use of ranpirnase for the treatment of external genital warts caused by human papillomavirus [ 15]. In the case of Ebola virus, ranpirnase inhibited replication of the virus in cell culture and protected mice when administered pre- and postexposure [ 18].
